class="SetPageTerm-sideContent"><a class="SetPageTerm-definitionText"><span class="TermText notranslate lang-en">Resolving conflict by utilizing a structural change</span></a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div aria-label="Term" class="SetPageTerms-term"><div class="SetPageTerm has-definitionText is-showing"><div class="SetPageTerm-inner"><div class="SetPageTerm-contentWrapper"><div class="SetPageTerm-content"><div class="SetPageTerm-side SetPageTerm-smallSide"><div class="SetPageTerm-sideContent"><a class="SetPageTerm-wordText"><span class="TermText notranslate lang-en">Altering the relationship</span></a></div></div><div class="SetPageTerm-side SetPageTerm-largeSide"><div class="SetPageTerm-sideContent"><a class="SetPageTerm-definitionText"><span class="TermText notranslate lang-en">Attempt to resolve conflict through the use of civil discussion</span></a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><div style="display:none"><span>Assemble-to-order</span><span>Strategies that create more customized products from a limited number of options</span><span>Chester Barnard</span><span>A member of the administrative school who believed organizations had to create positive reinforcements and minimize negative inducements in order to encourage cooperation</span><span>Benchmarking</span><span>Involves a manger or team of employees going to other companies and observing their processes</span><span>Bottom-up communication</span><span>Communication that comes from employees and is directed upward toward senior management</span><span>Boundary spanning roles</span><span>People on the periphery of the organization who spend a portion of their time looking out into the environment</span><span>Brainstorming</span><span>A method of rapidly throwing out ideas with the goal of generating more ideas using the principle of synergy</span><span>Bureaucracy</span><span>Max Weber&#x27;s creation of files that provided written documentation of actions taken and rules to govern all routine office functions</span><span>Business ethics</span><span>The beliefs about appropriate behaviors in the work place</span><span>Business Process Reengineering (BPR)</span><span>Evaluation of business activities or processes to eliminate unneeded steps</span><span>Centralized</span><span>A type of organization in which decisions are made at high levels</span><span>Certainty</span><span>A situation where the manager has full information about goals, options, and the outcomes associated with each alternative</span><span>Chain of command</span><span>Links each employee to a manager who is linked to another manager until the chain reaches the most senior manager, forming a clear and distinct line of authority</span><span>Classical approach</span><span>Decision-making process grounded in the view that the manager operates in the best economic interests of the organization</span><span>Coaching</span><span>Process of providing feedback and offering suggestions for improvement more frequently</span><span>Coercive power</span><span>Use threats of punishments to get subordinates to do things</span><span>Cohesiveness</span><span>Often defined as the extent to which members are attracted and wish to remain with the group</span><span>Collaboration</span><span>Means of handling conflict that is high on self-interest but also meets the other party&#x27;s interests</span><span>Commitment</span><span>Owning or identifying with the goals and intended results of a team</span><span>Committee</span><span>A cross-function group with a permanent role that meets regularly to share information and make decisions</span><span>Communication</span><span>Process of transmitting information to others; one of the most useful tools for overcoming resistance to change</span><span>Competitor</span><span>Style of handling conflict where individuals act in their own self-interest without concern for the interests of the other party</span><span>Completeness</span><span>Amount if information that is available for making decisions</span><span>Conceptual skills</span><span>A mental map of the organization and what impacts it</span><span>Concurrent</span><span>Controls are employed during the process</span><span>Conflict aftermath</span><span>Sow the seeds for future conflicts, which may lead to more consequential and costly actions</span><span>Consideration</span><span>Leadership dimension that involves listening to workers, being supportive, and encouraging them</span><span>Contingency plan</span><span>A plan that is put in place to address unexpected events</span><span>Control or regulation of emotions</span><span>Ability to project a positive outlook and deal with negative emotions that arise</span><span>Control systems</span><span>Assure that organizational processes are doing what they were intended to do without excessive expenditures of resources</span><span>Controlling</span><span>Assessing whether work has been done in a manner that is consistent with the previous functions</span><span>Co-optation</span><span>Giving an opinion leader or resistor a prominent role in the change process</span><span>Coordination</span><span>An aspect of organizing; one of the basic devices int he hierarchy or chain of command</span><span>Cost leadership</span><span>A strategy of separation based on the price</span><span>Costs</span><span>A component of efficiency measures</span><span>Cross-functional</span><span>Temporary teams that are comprised of people from different areas in the organization, each with a unique perspective and different information about the problem</span><span>Customized services</span><span>Small volume and specific to customer needs</span><span>Decentralized</span><span>Structures where the authority for making decisions is at the lower levels</span><span>Decision support systems (DSS)</span><span>Models that combine information based on historical relationships</span><span>Development</span><span>Provide skills for the future</span><span>Diagonal communication</span><span>Exchange of information between individuals in different units and levels of the company</span><span>Different assessments</span><span>Legitimate disagreement with the nature of the proposed changes</span><span>Differentation</span><span>A competitive strategy technique that finds some basis for being different</span><span>Direct pressure</span><span>Occurs when opposing views are presented</span><span>Directive</span><span>Type of leader behavior that tells the subordinate how to perform, specifying steps with details on how to accomplish them</span><span>Dissastisfiers</span><span>Context-related factors that turn employees off, such as pay, working conditions, and coworkers and supervisor relations</span><span>Division of labor</span><span>Tasks are divided and employees become specialized in performing certain tasks</span><span>Divisional</span><span>Structure that can be based on products, geography, customers, or even materials</span><span>Documentation</span><span>Managers communicate decisions and need to document the actions taken</span><span>Duality of command</span><span>With a matrix scheme, workers have both a functional and product manager, which may result in conflicting requests from each of the managers</span><span>Education</span><span>Method the helps address concerns about change</span><span>Effectiveness</span><span>Achieving the right goals</span><span>Efficiency</span><span>The amount of resources expended in accomplishing goals, often referred to as the ratio of inputs to outputs; measured in terms of how quickly information can be sent or how many people can receive the information</span><span>Empathy</span><span>Ability to respond according to the emotional needs of others</span><span>Employee relations</span><span>Serves the functions of communicating and working with non-union employees</span><span>Employee-centered</span><span>Emphasis on styles and behaviors of employees</span><span>Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP)</span><span>Term that refers to the integrated information systems that support all business functions and their data storage needs</span><span>Environment</span><span>Final contingency factor for organizing, often described in terms of stability and complexity</span><span>Equal Employement Opportunity (EEO)</span><span>All employment practices are based on merit and not race, religion, color, sex, or national origin</span><span>Essential functions</span><span>Critical components of a job that readily determines whether a disability would prevent someone from actually performing the job</span><span>Expectancy</span><span>Belief that effort will lead to performance, first component of expectancy thoery</span><span>Expense centor</span><span>One of the most common responsibility centers, where responsibility is maintained for staying under expense targets</span><span>Expert power</span><span>Derived from knowledge and information</span><span>Expert systems (ES)</span><span>Tires to extract knowledge from humans codify it into decision rules or trees</span><span>Explicit or implicit coercion</span><span>Occurs when managers tell employees that changes are vital and they must accept them and become involved; failure to do so will result in sanctions and punishments</span><span>External equity</span><span>Once the internal ranking of jobs is done, then the prevailing pay rates in other companies are examined</span><span>Facilitation and support</span><span>Another means available to managers in an attempt at reducing resistance to change</span><span>Henry Fayol</span><span>A French mining executive who was instrumental in the development of the functions of management; identified fourteen principles of management that remain the bedrock of administrative practices</span><span>Feedback</span><span>Controls employed at the end of a process or the production cycle, asking subordinates to repeat a message to check for accuracy</span><span>Feedforward</span><span>Controls employed at the beginning of the process of the production cycle</span><span>Felt conflict</span><span>&quot;Hot&quot; or strong emotional response, which can result in anger or hostility</span><span>Finished goods</span><span>The products that are packaged and ready to be shipped to customers</span><span>Flat structures</span><span>Organizations that delegate decision-making to lower levels</span><span>Flexibility</span><span>Can involve changes in the volume of products made or product features</span><span>Flexible and adaptive structures</span><span>Can readily adapt to changing conditions in the environment</span><span>Flexible manufacturing (FM)</span><span>Configuration of parts and manufacturing systems that allows for both low cost and high variety</span><span>Focus</span><span>A competitive strategy that identifies a specific consumer group, or niche, in the marketplace that the company will serve</span><span>Mary Parker Follett</span><span>Administrative School writer who applied her training psychology to understand workers and their reactions to management</span><span>Forming</span><span>Initial stage of group development when questions arise about the purpose of the group and if members will be able to attain it</span><span>Framing</span><span>Context or situation in which an issue arrose</span><span>Functional structures</span><span>Grouping people according to basic functions of the business they perform</span><span>Functional team</span><span>Individuals who are permanently assigned to a team to do their work</span><span>General Environment</span><span>The broadest category of issues in the environment to which managers must pay attention; includes the economy and technology as well as legal-political and socio-cultural issues</span><span>Goal displacement</span><span>Occurs when the budget becomes the ultimate goal, not profitability or doing more business</span><span>Goals</span><span>Statements of desired results</span><span>Hawthorne studies</span><span>Landmark research study that investigated the impact of lighting on productivity in a manufacturing plant in suburban Chicago</span><span>Horizontal communication</span><span>Lateral exchange between individuals</span><span>Hostile work environment</span><span>Situation in which the repeated actions of a coworker or supervisor create an environment whereby the employee cannot advance or work comfortably</span><span>Human capital</span><span>The economic value of skills, abilities, and competencies of a company&#x27;s workforce</span><span>Human resource management (HRM)</span><span>Activities for attracting, retaining, and enhancing the performance of managers and workers in organizations</span><span>Human skills</span><span>The ability to relate with others, communicate well, and make requests in a manner that will motivate employees rather than offend them</span><span>illusion of invulnerability</span><span>Belief that a group can do no wrong and is beyond criticism</span><span>illusions of unanimity</span><span>Premature assumption that consensus has been achieved</span><span>Immediate environment</span><span>Components that have a specific and direct impact on the business; may also be referred to as stakeholders; includes customers, competitors, suppliers, labor organizations, and the community</span><span>Incompatible reward systems</span><span>When rewards and goals are at odds with one another</span><span>Influence</span><span>Tendency to persuade others by using emotional arguments</span><span>Influencing strategies</span><span>An attempt to influence the forces in the environment</span><span>Information</span><span>Data made useful for management</span><span>Information management</span><span>Uses computer hardware and software programs to store and make information readily retrievable to managers, as they need it to make decisions</span><span>Inherent morality</span><span>Belief that whatever the group does must be right</span><span>Initiation of structure</span><span>Dimension of leadership pertaining to tasks</span><span>Inputs</span><span>Pertains to equity theory and may include effort, education, skill, or training; the individual members and the knowledge and information they possess</span><span>Instrumentality</span><span>Reflects the link between performing and the outcomes associated with good performance, second component of the expectancy theory</span><span>Integration mechanisms</span><span>Ways to achieve coordination without going to a full-blown matrix design; examples include direct contact, the use of liaisons, and task forces</span><span>interdependent</span><span>Situation in which the tasks that are performed by units or individuals rely heavily on one another</span><span>Inter-group conflict</span><span>Conflict between different units or groups</span><span>Internal equity</span><span>A system set up based on job rankings and ratings</span><span>Interpersonal conflict</span><span>Conflict between two individuals</span><span>Interval</span><span>A time-based schedule of reinforcement</span><span>Intragroup conflict</span><span>Conflict among members of a team or a group</span><span>Inventory management</span><span>Maintaining supplies of raw materials and products and coordinating their movements through the value chain</span><span>Investment center</span><span>When the capital budget is added to the profit center</span><span>Job analysis</span><span>Studying jobs to create a job description and job specifications</span><span>Job description</span><span>Statement of tasks performed on the job and the conditions under which they were performed</span><span>Job evaluation</span><span>All jobs are categorized or ranked on the level of responsibility, skill required, and amount of supervision given and received</span><span>Job Incumbent</span><span>Someone currently performing the job</span><span>Job specification</span><span>A list of skills, knowledge, and abilities needed to perform the job</span><span>Job-centered</span><span>Focus on efficiency, meeting schedules, and task accomplishment</span><span>Joint ventures or parternships</span><span>Involve cooperative agreements between firms</span><span>Justice</span><span>Assumes that all should be treated with fairness and impartiality</span><span>Kanban</span><span>System developed by Toyota to solve a problem with defective parts</span><span>Labor relations</span><span>Works with employees in organized labor unions</span><span>Lack of trust</span><span>Little or no faith in the person making the changes</span><span>Latent conflict</span><span>Something has happened but the employee has not yet perceived it</span><span>Laws</span><span>Provide guidelines for the greater good of the community</span><span>Leader relations</span><span>Refers to whether or not subordinates are willing to trust and follow the leader</span><span>Leadership</span><span>A set of behaviors that inspire and direct employees in the performance of their tasks</span><span>Leading</span><span>Making the plans and structures work as designed</span><span>Least preferred coworker</span><span>Term used by Fiedler to describe a situational, or contingency, approach to leadership; also referred to as LPC</span><span>Legitimate power</span><span>Traditional form of authority</span><span>Line employee</span><span>Workers who make a product or deliver a service</span><span>Logisitics</span><span>The process of getting finished products to customers</span><span>Low tolerance for change</span><span>Aversion to change, which brings uncertainty and discomfort</span><span>Make-to-order</span><span>Most highly customized strategy whereby each product may have unique customized specifications and thus volumes are low</span><span>Make-to-stock</span><span>Strategy that relies on inventory</span><span>Management Information Systems (MIS)</span><span>The hardware and software that provides managers with needed and timely information</span><span>Management of Technology</span><span>Part of operations management that continues to search for cost effective ways to improve productivity through new and improved technologies.</span><span>Manifest conflict</span><span>The person experiencing conflict takes some action and the other person often responds in kind</span><span>Manipulation</span><span>Selective use of information and structuring of events; highly risky</span><span>Abraham Maslow</span><span>Proposed five categories of need that influence human motivation</span><span>Matrix</span><span>Organizing scheme that combines functional design with product teams</span><span>Douglas McGregor</span><span>Influential writer from the human perspective who explained that workers responded to the attitudes of their managers, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy</span><span>Mind-guards</span><span>Individuals who seek to protect the group from dissenting viewpoints</span><span>Moral rights</span><span>The absolute rights that people have such as freedom of consent, freedom of privacy, freedom of conscience, freedom of speech, and right to due process</span><span>Morals</span><span>Fundamental values that societies impart to their members about right and wrong</span><span>Motivate</span><span>Emotional quality that drives people to achieve</span><span>Motivation</span><span>The forces that drive people to behave in ways that energize, direct, and sustain their work behavior and performance</span><span>Moving</span><span>Changes are made in, work people, structure, technology, and relationships</span><span>Needs Analysis</span><span>Looks at issues in the organization that could be improved with training</span><span>Negligent hiring</span><span>Suits filed when the employer does not carefully review prior histories</span><span>Norming</span><span>Third stage of group development whereby members realize that all will contribute in different ways</span><span>Norms</span><span>Informal rules that guide behavior</span><span>Objectives</span><span>Specific statements of intended outcomes</span><span>Organizational chart</span><span>The most concrete embodiment of the organizing function; most charts use rectangles to represent departments or other units, with lines showing the connection and formal authority relationships</span><span>Organizing</span><span>The pattern of relationship among workers</span><span>Outputs</span><span>Relates to equity theory; can be extrinsic (pay, promotions, bonuses, or recognition) or intrinsic (satisfaction and a sense of achievement); results that should occur at the end of a group&#x27;s activities</span><span>Parochial self-interest</span><span>New changes that may reduce an individual&#x27;s status and influence.</span><span>Participation and involvement</span><span>Naturally reduces resistance to change</span><span>Participative</span><span>Style of leadership that involves subordinates in decision-making, asking for their input and involvement</span><span>Perceived conflict</span><span>Person is aware that his or her goals are blocked or potentially blocked by someone&#x27;s action</span><span>Performing</span><span>Fourth stage of group development with roles readily shifting as other members take on these roles as needed; results in greater cooperation and more productive ways of problem solving</span><span>Planning</span><span>Specifying desired organizational results, or outcomes, as well as identifying the means for achieving these results</span><span>Plans</span><span>Specify the means, or activities, that are chosen to reach the goals</span><span>Political model</span><span>Decision contexts that do not have an objective set of criteria and priorities; the determination of what is valued and viewed as important is based on political processes</span><span>Position power</span><span>Involves formal authority and the ability to reward, punish, and fire</span><span>Positive reinforcement</span><span>When a positive condition is presented following behavior</span><span>Powe</span><span>Ability to get others to do things</span><span>Process conflict</span><span>involves differences in how group work is performed</span><span>Process loss</span><span>A sub-optimal decision process whereby the available information is not shared and used in the decision-making process; dynamics within the group that limit or prevent synergy</span><span>Profit center</span><span>A responsibility center that subtracts expenses from revenue</span><span>Progressive Discipline</span><span>A series of steps that get progressively more severe in their consequences for the employee</span><span>Project</span><span>A onetime set of activities with a definite beginning and ending point</span><span>Public relations</span><span>Release of information to the public, often coordinated through a media campaign, to influence public opinion on a particular issue</span><span>Punishment</span><span>When something averse or negative happens following a behavior</span><span>Quality</span><span>Products and services must be consistently produced with minimal errors; type of information that accurately portrays what is going on in an organization</span><span>Ratio</span><span>A schedule of reinforcement based on behavioe</span><span>Rationalized</span><span>Method of explaining away disconfirming data</span><span>Raw materials</span><span>The components before any transformation by the company</span><span>Readiness</span><span>Hershey-Blanchard&#x27;s Life Cycle or Situational Theory based on whether or not the subordinate is ready for delegation; determined by education or experience, confidence and motivation, or willingness to assume responsibility</span><span>Real-time systems</span><span>Update the database automatically, assuring greater timeliness and accuracy</span><span>Reasonable accomodations</span><span>Result of the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act, pertaining to employees who can perform essential job functions</span><span>Redundancy</span><span>Sending critical information through multiple channels or media</span><span>Referent power</span><span>Results when subordinates identify with managers and want to be like them</span><span>Refreezing</span><span>A &quot;firming up&quot; of the new processes</span><span>Relationship conflict</span><span>Involves tension and friction between members of the group</span><span>Relevance</span><span>Refers to information needed to make decisions</span><span>Replacement chart</span><span>For each critical position, three potential replacements are listed along with their readiness for moving up</span><span>resource scarcity</span><span>When resources are limited, they may need to be taken from somewhere else</span><span>Revenue center</span><span>Another type of responsibility center that is focused more externally and establishes, within the center, a set responsibility for generating revenue targets</span><span>Richness</span><span>Capacity for a medium for information</span><span>Risk</span><span>A situation where the goals and options are known but the outcomes are not; willingness to take a chance</span><span>Role ambiguities</span><span>When the duties and boundaries assigned to an individual are not clear</span><span>Satisfaction-progression</span><span>Once the lower-order needs are satisfied, then those above start to emerge as motivational factors</span><span>Satisficing</span><span>Idea that people search for minimally acceptable, not optimal solution, when making decisions</span><span>Satisfiers</span><span>Content-related factors that excite workers such as responsibility, advancement, and personal growth</span><span>Scientific management</span><span>Frederick Taylor&#x27;s systematic approach to studying work in order to find a more rational way of conducting business</span><span>Self-awareness</span><span>Leaders who are in touch with their own emotions and internal states</span><span>Self-censorship</span><span>Situation in which groups may have doubts but fail to raise them</span><span>Self-oriented roles</span><span>Sets of behaviors that members engage in at the expense of the group</span><span>Single-use plans</span><span>Plans that may only be used once</span><span>Size</span><span>A contingency for organizing based on growth and shrinkage</span><span>Skill-pay</span><span>Employees are paid more for each additional skill they learn on the job</span><span>Skills</span><span>Technical, interpersonal, and problem solving capabilities that contribute to the overall effectiveness of a team</span><span>SMART</span><span>Objectives that are Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-based</span><span>Socio-emotional</span><span>Roles that help maintain good relationships among members so work can be accomplished; also known as maintenance roles</span><span>Span of managment</span><span>The number of workers who report directly to one manager</span><span>Specialization</span><span>By performing a small set of tasks, greater volume in productivity can be achieved</span><span>Staff</span><span>Employees who do not directly assist in making the product but provide critical advice or information</span><span>Standardized services</span><span>Services produced in large volumes</span><span>Standing plans</span><span>Plans that are used over and over; also known as recurring plans</span><span>Stereotyped</span><span>May be applied to those who present alternative viewpoints</span><span>Storming</span><span>Second stage of group development in which members notice that others seem to have slightly different agendas or goals</span><span>Strategy</span><span>The set of activities designed to help an organization or business achieve its goals; an organizational contingency factor that revolves around choices and focuses on some areas instead of others</span><span>Subordinate characteristics</span><span>Situational factor in which the ability, skill levels, needs, and motivations impact the choice of leadership style</span><span>Supply Chain Management (SCM)</span><span>Implies the management of the entire value chain, from suppliers through to customers</span><span>Supportive</span><span>Leadership style in which the manager asks questions and encourages the subordinate</span><span>SWOT</span><span>A process of analysis that involves looking at Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats</span><span>Synergy</span><span>Principle best described as &quot;the whole is greater than the sum of the parts&quot;</span><span>Synergy effect</span><span>When individuals share thoughts, one person&#x27;s ideas stimulate another to think of issues that would not have arisen if working alone</span><span>Systems theory</span><span>Concept developed in science and later applied to management; organizations should be viewed as open systems that require energy, people, ideas, raw materials, capital, and information inputs from the environment</span><span>Tall structures</span><span>Characterized by layers of decision-making, which takes longer for decisions and communication to move up and down the hierarchy and slows adaptability</span><span>Task conflict</span><span>Involves differences in opinion about the task facing the group</span><span>Task forces</span><span>Temporary teams for a specific purpose; also referred to as ad hoc groups</span><span>Task structure</span><span>Relates to whether the tasks performed by the group are defined and clear</span><span>Task-oriented</span><span>Task roles address the content issues that the groups are working on</span><span>Technical skills</span><span>The application of specific, learned knowledge</span><span>Technology</span><span>Set of activities that transforms inputs into outputs</span><span>Time</span><span>Rate at which customers want products delivered</span><span>Timeliness</span><span>The speed at which information becomes available</span><span>Top-down communication</span><span>Communication from senior management that is efficient but can cause ambiguity if not written clearly</span><span>Uncertain</span><span>Situations that involve known goals but incomplete option information, and the likelihood or probability of outcomes is not known`</span><span>Unfreezing</span><span>To make needed changes, ties to the old way must be loosened</span><span>Universalism</span><span>Looks at the means and intentions of decisions; the ends are not the most important but rather the duties and obligations followed in getting there</span><span>Utilitarian</span><span>Focuses on the outcomes or consequences of decisions and is based primarily on costs and benefits</span><span>Valence</span><span>Value of outcomes; third component of expectancy theory</span><span>Vertical communication</span><span>Communicating information up and down the hierarchy</span><span>Vertical team</span><span>Teams that include a supervisor and several layers in the chain of command</span><span>Virtual groups</span><span>Groups that never meet but instead interact electronically; groups are geographically distributed, often around the globe</span><span>Work environment</span><span>Type of situational factor whereby the amount of structure in the task itself influences directive behaviors</span><span>Work-in-progress</span><span>The pieces that will be assembled into the final product</span><span>Telecommuting</span><span>Working at home by using a computer terminal electronically linked to one&#x27;s place of employment</span><span>Just in time (JIT)</span><span>An inventory-management approach in which supplies arrive just when needed for production or resale</span><span>Small batch inventory (SBI)</span><span>used to describe a small production run, typically less than 500 units (garments).</span><span>Frederick Taylor</span><span>Pioneer in the scientific management school</span><span>Annual operating plan</span><span>Describes an organization&#x27;s short-term strategies, goals and objectives for the given/upcoming year. Time frame is typically 1 year</span><span>Arbitration</span><span>The use of an arbitrator to settle a dispute</span><span>Mediation</span><span>Negotiation to resolve differences conducted by some impartial party</span><span>Flextime</span><span>A schedule that allows workers to choose work hours that fit their particular needs`</span><span>High-self monitoring</span><span>Change behaviors according to the context</span><span>Machiavellian</span><span>the ends justify the means</span><span>Halo error</span><span>Allowing the assessment of the employee on one dimension to spread to that employee&#x27;s ratings on other dimensions</span><span>Transactional Leadership</span><span>Leadership based on an exchange process in which followers are rewarded for good performance and punished for poor performance</span><span>Management by Objectives (MBO)</span><span>a program that encompasses specific goals, participatively set, for an explicit time period, with feedback on goal progress</span><span>Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)</span><span>A method for analyzing the tasks involved in completing a given project, estimating the time needed to complete each task, and identifying the minimum time needed to complete the total project.</span><span>Boston Consulting Group Matrix</span><span>Is a chart that was created by Bruce D. Henderson for the Boston Consulting Group in 1970 to help corporations to analyze their product lines. It classified products as stars, question marks, cash cows or dogs.</span><span>Theory X</span><span>Assumes that workers are basically lazy, error-prone, and extrinsically motivated by money and, thus, should be directed from above.</span><span>Theory Y</span><span>Assumes that, given challenge and freedom, workers are motivated to achieve self-esteem and to demonstrate their competence and creativity</span><span>Porter&#x27;s Five Forces</span><span>threat of entry, threat of substitute, supplier power, buyer power, and competitive rivalry</span><span>Ohio State Leadership Studies</span><span>defined leader consideration and initiating-structure behaviors as independent dimensions of leadership</span><span>Telling</span><span>High structure, low consideration</span><span>Utilitarian view of ethics</span><span>View that says ethical decisions are made solely on the basis of their outcomes or consequences</span><span>E-business enabled organization</span><span>1. Uses the internet to perform    }// End Rollbar Snippet 2. Its traditional business functions 3. Better but not to sell anything</span><span>Hofstede</span><span>individualism vs. collectivismmasculine vs. feminineuncertainty avoidancetime orientation</span><span>According to Hofstede, degree of individualism in a country is closely related to what?</span><span>wealth</span><span>Polycentric</span><span>The belief that locals of the host country know their culture better and should run a business accordingly</span><span>Knowledge Management</span><span>finding the right information, keeping the information in a readily accessible place, and making the information known to everyone in the firm</span><span>Peter Drucker</span><span>The hierarchy of needs theory. Believes consistency is key to good leadership</span><span>Henri Fayol</span><span>French engineer and industrialistfirst to identify the major functions of management</span><span>Elton Mayo</span><span>Hawthorne Studies</span><span>F.W. Taylor</span><span>Father of scientific management</span><span>Max Weber</span><span>Father of sociology. Argued that in a capitalist society inequalities would lead to conflict, but that there would be more than one source of conflict. Argued that there were several factors that moderated people&#x27;s reaction to inequality.</span><span>Frank and Lillian Gilbreth</span><span>Employed motion study to simplify work and improve productivity (scientific management)</span><span>Joseph Juran</span><span>Believed quality issues were at fault of the manager</span><span>Entropy</span><span>System&#x27;s tendency to go toward inefficiency if left to its own devices</span><span>Executive Champion</span><span>An executive who supports a new technology and protects the product champion of the innovation.</span><span>Technical innovator</span><span>A person who develops a new technology or has the key skills to install and operate the technology</span><span>Product Champion</span><span>A manager who takes &quot;ownership&quot; of a project and provides the leadership and vision that take a product from the idea stage to the final customer</span><span>Henry Mintzberg</span><span>Divided manager&#x27;s job into three types: interpersonal, informational, decisional</span><span>Queuing theory</span><span>The mathematical modeling of waiting lines</span><span>MBTI</span><span>Myers-Briggs Type Indicator</span><span>Laissez-faire</span><span>a policy or attitude of letting things take their own course, without interfering</span></div><div class="siycb3m"><button type="button" aria-label="See more" class="AssemblyButtonBase AssemblyPrimaryButton--default AssemblyButtonBase--medium AssemblyButtonBase--padding AssemblyButtonBase--fullWidth"><span>See more</span></button></div><div
